query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Ora sen va per un secreto calle, 2 tra ’l muro de la terra e li martìri, 3 lo mio maestro, e io dopo le spalle.
query.result: 1 Now he goes by a secret path, 2 between the wall of the earth and the martyrs, 3 my master, and I following behind his shoulders.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
4 «O virtù somma, che per li empi giri 5 mi volvi», cominciai, «com’ a te piace, 6 parlami, e sodisfammi a’ miei disiri.
query.result: 4 “O highest virtue, that through the wicked turns 5 me, as it pleases you, 6 speak to me, and satisfy my desires.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
7 La gente che per li sepolcri giace 8 potrebbesi veder? già son levati 9 tutt’ i coperchi, e nessun guardia face».
query.result: 7 Could the people who lie in the sepulchers 8 be seen? Already the lids are removed, 9 and no guard makes [any] watch.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
10 E quelli a me: «Tutti saran serrati 11 quando di Iosafàt qui torneranno 12 coi corpi che là sù hanno lasciati.
query.result: 10 And he to me: “All will be closed 11 when they return here from Josaphat 12 with the bodies that they left up there.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Suo cimitero da questa parte hanno 14 con Epicuro tutti suoi seguaci, 15 che l’anima col corpo morta fanno.
query.result: 13 Their cemetery is on this side 14 with Epicurus all his followers, 15 who make the soul dead with the body.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
16 Però a la dimanda che mi faci 17 quinc’ entro satisfatto sarà tosto, 18 e al disio ancor che tu mi taci».
query.result: 16 Therefore to the question that you make to me 17 here within will be satisfied quickly, 18 and to the desire also that you are silent to me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 E io: «Buon duca, non tegno riposto 20 a te mio cuor se non per dicer poco, 21 e tu m’hai non pur mo a ciò disposto».
query.result: 19 And I: “Good guide, I do not hold back 20 to you my heart if not to say little, 21 and you have not only now disposed me to this.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 «O Tosco che per la città del foco 23 vivo ten vai così parlando onesto, 24 piacciati di restare in questo loco.
query.result: 22 O Tuscan who through the city of fire 23 living you go thus speaking honestly, 24 be pleased to remain in this place.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 La tua loquela ti fa manifesto 26 di quella nobil patrïa natio, 27 a la qual forse fui troppo molesto».
query.result: 25 Your speech makes you manifest 26 of that noble homeland native, 27 to which perhaps I was too troublesome.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Subitamente questo suono uscìo 29 d’una de l’arche; però m’accostai, 30 temendo, un poco più al duca mio.
query.result: 28 Suddenly this sound came out 29 from one of the arches; therefore I approached, 30 fearing, a little more to my guide.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Ed el mi disse: «Volgiti! Che fai? 32 Vedi là Farinata che s’è dritto: 33 da la cintola in sù tutto ’l vedrai».
query.result: 31 And he to me said: “Turn yourself! What do you do? 32 See there Farinata who has straightened himself: 33 from the waist up all of him you will see.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Io avea già il mio viso nel suo fitto; 35 ed el s’ergea col petto e con la fronte 36 com’ avesse l’inferno a gran dispitto.

Please translate each line literally into English.
37 E l’animose man del duca e pronte 38 mi pinser tra le sepulture a lui, 39 dicendo: «Le parole tue sien conte».
query.result: 37 And the spirited and ready hands of the guide 38 pressed me among the sepulchers to him, 39 saying: “Let your words be counted.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Com’ io al piè de la sua tomba fui, 41 guardommi un poco, e poi, quasi sdegnoso, 42 mi dimandò: «Chi fuor li maggior tui?».
query.result: 40 As I was at the foot of his tomb, 41 he looked at me a little, and then, almost disdainful, 42 he asked me: “Who were your greatest ancestors?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 «S’ei fur cacciati, ei tornar d’ogne parte», 50 rispuos’ io lui, «l’una e l’altra fïata; 51 ma i vostri non appreser ben quell’ arte».

Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Allor surse a la vista scoperchiata 53 un’ombra, lungo questa, infino al mento: 54 credo che s’era in ginocchie levata.
query.result: 52 Then arose to the uncovered sight 53 a shadow, along this one, up to the chin: 54 I believe that she had risen to her knees.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Dintorno mi guardò, come talento 56 avesse di veder s’altri era meco; 57 e poi che ’l sospecciar fu tutto spento,
58 piangendo disse: «Se per questo cieco 59 carcere vai per altezza d’ingegno, 60 mio figlio ov’ è? e perché non è teco?».
query.result:
55 Around me she looked, as if she had 56 the talent to see if another was with me; 57 and after the suspicion was all extinguished,
58 weeping she said: “If for this blind 59 prison you go by height of intellect, 60 my son where is he? and why is he not with you?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 E io a lui: «Da me stesso non vegno: 62 colui ch’attende là, per qui mi mena 63 forse cui Guido vostro ebbe a disdegno».
query.result: 61 And I to him: “Not from myself do I come: 62 the one who waits there, through whom he leads me 63 perhaps the one whom your Guido had in disdain.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Le sue parole e ’l modo de la pena 65 m’avean di costui già letto il nome; 66 però fu la risposta così piena.

Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Di sùbito drizzato gridò: «Come? 68 dicesti “elli ebbe”? non viv’ elli ancora? 69 non fiere li occhi suoi lo dolce lume?».
query.result: 67 Suddenly straightened he cried: “How? 68 did you say “he had”? does he not live still? 69 do not pierce his eyes the sweet light?”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Quando s’accorse d’alcuna dimora 71 ch’io facëa dinanzi a la risposta, 72 supin ricadde e più non parve fora.
query.result: 70 When he perceived some delay 71 that I made before the answer, 72 supine he fell back and seemed no longer there.

73 But that other magnanimous one, to whom remained 74 posted to me, did not change aspect, 75 nor moved neck, nor bent his side;
76 and continuing to the first saying, 77 “If they have that art,” he said, “badly learned, 78 this torments me more than this sight.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Ma non cinquanta volte fia raccesa 80 la faccia de la donna che qui regge, 81 che tu saprai quanto quell’ arte pesa.
query.result: 79 But not fifty times will be rekindled 80 the face of the woman who rules here, 81 that you will know how much that art weighs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 E se tu mai nel dolce mondo regge, 83 dimmi: perché quel popolo è sì empio 84 incontr’ a’ miei in ciascuna sua legge?».
query.result: 82 And if you ever in the sweet world return, 83 tell me: why is that people so impious 84 against mine in each of its laws?».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 Ond’ io a lui: «Lo strazio e ’l grande scempio 86 che fece l’Arbia colorata in rosso, 87 tal orazion fa far nel nostro tempio».
query.result: 85 And I to him: “The tearing and the great devastation 86 that the Arbia made red in red, 87 such a prayer makes to be done in our temple.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Poi ch’ebbe sospirando il capo mosso, 89 «A ciò non fu’ io sol», disse, «né certo 90 sanza cagion con li altri sarei mosso.
query.result: 88 After he had moved his head, sighing, 89 “Not for this was I alone,” he said, “nor certainly 90 would I have been moved with the others without a cause.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Ma fu’ io solo, là dove sofferto 92 fu per ciascun di tòrre via Fiorenza, 93 colui che la difesi a viso aperto».
query.result: 91 But I was alone, there where suffered 92 was for each one of turning away from Florence, 93 the one who defended it with open face.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 «Deh, se riposi mai vostra semenza», 95 prega’ io lui, «solvetemi quel nodo 96 che qui ha ’nviluppata mia sentenza.
query.result: 94 “Oh, if ever your seed finds rest,” 95 I pray to him, “loosen for me that knot 96 that here has enveloped my sentence.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 El par che voi veggiate, se ben odo, 98 dinanzi quel che ’l tempo seco adduce, 99 e nel presente tenete altro modo».
query.result: 97 He seems to see, if I hear well, 98 before what time brings with it, 99 and in the present you hold another way.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 «Noi veggiam, come quei c’ha mala luce, 101 le cose», disse, «che ne son lontano; 102 cotanto ancor ne splende il sommo duce.

Please translate each line literally into English.
103 Quando s’appressano o son, tutto è vano 104 nostro intelletto; e s’altri non ci apporta, 105 nulla sapem di vostro stato umano.
query.result: 103 When they approach or are here, all is vain 104 our intellect; and if another does not bring it to us, 105 we know nothing of your human state.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
106 Però comprender puoi che tutta morta 107 fia nostra conoscenza da quel punto 108 che del futuro fia chiusa la porta».
query.result: 106 Therefore you can understand that all dead 107 will be our knowledge from that point 108 that of the future is closed the door.”

109 Then, as with my guilt stricken, 110 I said: “Now will you say to that fallen one 111 that his son is still joined with the living;
112 and if I was, before, mute to the answer, 113 make them know that I did so because he was thinking 114 already of the error that you have absolved me from.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 E già ’l maestro mio mi richiamava; 116 per ch’i’ pregai lo spirto più avaccio 117 che mi dicesse chi con lu’ istava.

Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Dissemi: «Qui con più di mille giaccio: 119 qua dentro è ’l secondo Federico 120 e ’l Cardinale; e de li altri mi taccio».

Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Indi s’ascose; e io inver’ l’antico 122 poeta volsi i passi, ripensando 123 a quel parlar che mi parea nemico.
query.result: 121 Then he hid himself; and I turned my steps 122 towards the ancient poet, remembering 123 that speech which seemed to me hostile.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Elli si mosse; e poi, così andando, 125 mi disse: «Perché se’ tu sì smarrito?». 126 E io li sodisfeci al suo dimando.
query.result: 124 He moved; and then, while going, 125 he said to me: “Why are you so lost?” 126 And I satisfied him with his asking.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 «La mente tua conservi quel ch’udito 128 hai contra te», mi comandò quel saggio; 129 «e ora attendi qui», e drizzò ’l dito:
130 «quando sarai dinanzi al dolce raggio 131 di quella il cui bell’ occhio tutto vede, 132 da lei saprai di tua vita il vïaggio».
query.result:
127 “Let your mind retain what you have heard 128 against you,” commanded that wise man; 129 “and now wait here,” and he raised his finger:
130 “when you will be before the sweet ray 131 of her whose beautiful eye sees everything, 132 from her you will know of your life’s journey.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Appresso mosse a man sinistra il piede: 134 lasciammo il muro e gimmo inver’ lo mezzo 135 per un sentier ch’a una valle fiede,
136 che ’nfin là sù facea spiacer suo lezzo.
query.result:
133 Afterwards he moved his foot to the left; 134 we left the wall and went into the middle 135 along a path that led to a valley smelling of sorrow,
136 which up to there made displeasing its stench.
